JUDGMENT
2 FARLAM AJA
The facts, the relevant statutory provisions and case law and the contentions
of the parties are set out in the judgment of Van Heerden DCJ, which I have had the
advantage of reading. My reasons for respectfully disagreeing with his conclusion
follow.
A convenient starting point is a reference to the dictum of Miller J in Apalamah
v Santam Insurance Co Ltd, 1975(2) SA 229(D) 234 A-B which was
quoted with approval in SA Mutual Fire and General Insurance Co Ltd v Eyberg
1981(4) SA 318(A) 327 D-G. The proposition is that where the two statutes conflict
on the same topic the generality of the Prescription Act must yield to the third party
legislation. In this case the respondent contends that the references to an insane
person in the former and to a person detained under the mental health legislation in
the Agreement, pertain to the same topic. I have difficulty with this equation, as it
seems manifest that, whatever the degree of overlap, not all insane persons are
detained, and not all detained persons are insane. This is not one of the simple cases
such as minority and subjection to curatorship where the same words are used in

sections.facts: The case concerned a claim under the Road Accident Fund against Raphael Smith. The Fund's agreement with the claimant referred to an "insane person" while the claimant argued that the same clause should be read as referring to a "person detained under the mental health legislation". The dispute turned on whether these two expressions denoted the same legal category and therefore triggered the same statutory consequences.
sections.issues: The principal issue was whether the provisions of the Prescription Act (or other general legislation) conflicted with the specific terms of the Fund’s agreement concerning mental incapacity, and, if a conflict existed, which provision should prevail.
sections.principles: The court applied the doctrine that where a general statute conflicts with a more specific third‑party legislation, the specific provision prevails. This principle was drawn from Miller J’s dictum in Apalamah v Santam and reaffirmed in SA Mutual Fire and General Insurance v Eyberg. The analysis also examined the legal distinction between "insane" persons and persons "detained under mental health legislation".
sections.application: Justice Farlam AJA rejected the respondent’s contention that the two expressions were interchangeable, noting that not every insane person is detained and not every detained person is legally insane. Consequently, the court found no direct conflict between the general Prescription Act and the specific wording of the agreement, and the statutory hierarchy favored the agreement’s distinct terms.
sections.conclusion: The appeal was allowed in favour of the Road Accident Fund. The court concluded that the respondent’s argument about a shared legal category was untenable, and that the Fund’s position on the interpretation of the agreement and the applicability of the Prescription Act was affirmed.
